name: Rama
subtitle: Maryada Purushottama - The Perfect Man
description: Rama (Sanskrit: lord of virtue) is the seventh avatar of Vishnu and the central hero of the Ramayana, one of Hinduism's two great epics (composed by Valmiki, c. 5th-4th century BCE). As prince and later king of Ayodhya, Rama embodies dharma (righteous duty) in its most perfect form: he is the ideal son who accepts exile to preserve his father's honor, the ideal husband who rescues his wife Sita from the demon king Ravana, the ideal brother who inspires unwavering loyalty from Lakshmana and Bharata, and the ideal king whose rule became synonymous with utopia (Rama-rajya). His fourteen-year exile, alliance with Hanuman and the monkey army, and war against Lanka to rescue Sita constitute the Ramayana's main narrative. Rama is worshipped throughout India and Southeast Asia as the supreme exemplar of virtuous conduct.

parentage.divine: Vishnu - As seventh avatar, Rama is Vishnu incarnate for the destruction of Ravana
parentage.mortal: Dasharatha - King of Ayodhya; Kaushalya - Queen-mother
parentage.heritage: Ikshvaku/Solar Dynasty; born from divine nectar distributed by Vishnu

family.wife: Sita - Daughter of King Janaka, incarnation of goddess Lakshmi
family.brothers: Lakshmana (accompanied him in exile), Bharata (ruled in his name), Shatrughna

keyMyths.title: Birth and Breaking of Shiva's Bow
keyMyths.description: Rama was born to King Dasharatha after a fire sacrifice (putrakameshti yajna). Trained by sage Vishwamitra, the young Rama defended the sage's sacrifice and was taken to Mithila, where King Janaka offered his daughter Sita to whoever could string the bow of Shiva. Rama not only strung it but broke it, winning Sita's hand.

keyMyths.title: The Exile
keyMyths.description: On the eve of Rama's coronation, Queen Kaikeyi invoked boons from Dasharatha: crown Bharata king and exile Rama for fourteen years. To honor his father's word, Rama accepted exile without protest. Sita and Lakshmana insisted on accompanying him. This act of filial piety and dharma defines Rama's character.

keyMyths.title: The Abduction of Sita
keyMyths.description: In the forest, the demon Ravana, disguised as an ascetic, abducted Sita while Rama pursued a golden deer (actually demon Maricha). The dying vulture Jatayu informed Rama. This abduction sets in motion the epic's central conflict.

keyMyths.title: Alliance with Hanuman and the Monkey Army
keyMyths.description: Searching for Sita, Rama befriended the monkey king Sugriva and his minister Hanuman. Rama helped Sugriva defeat his brother Vali; in return, the monkey army joined his cause. Hanuman leaped across the ocean to Lanka, found Sita, and returned with news.
keyMyths.source: Valmiki Ramayana, Kishkindha Kanda & Sundara Kanda

keyMyths.title: The War Against Lanka
keyMyths.description: Rama's army built a bridge across the ocean to Lanka. In the great war, Rama slew Ravana's champions‚ÄîKumbhakarna, Indrajit‚Äîand finally defeated the ten-headed demon king himself with the Brahmastra. Sita was rescued after fourteen years.

keyMyths.title: Sita's Trial by Fire (Agni Pariksha)
keyMyths.description: To prove her purity after captivity in Lanka, Sita entered fire. Agni, god of fire, returned her unharmed, demonstrating her chastity. This controversial episode is interpreted variously: as Ravana holding only a shadow Sita, as patriarchal expectation, or as metaphysical truth.

keyMyths.title: Return and Rama-rajya
keyMyths.description: Rama returned to Ayodhya and was crowned king. His reign became known as Rama-rajya, the ideal kingdom where dharma prevailed, no one suffered, and justice ruled. This utopia remains the Hindu political ideal.

heroJourney.thresholdCrossing: Leaving Ayodhya for the forest, renouncing kingdom
heroJourney.ordeal: Sita's abduction; search across India; war against Lanka
heroJourney.allies: Hanuman, Sugriva, Vibhishana, the monkey army
heroJourney.transformation: From prince to exile to righteous warrior to ideal king

comparativeNotes.greek: Like Odysseus, Rama is exiled and must journey to reclaim what he lost; the faithful wife motif parallels Penelope and Sita
comparativeNotes.nearEastern: The demon-king antagonist parallels ancient Near Eastern chaos monsters; the divine hero defeating evil is universal
comparativeNotes.buddhist: The Ramayana is known throughout Buddhist Southeast Asia; the Dasharatha Jataka presents Rama as a bodhisattva
comparativeNotes.christian: Comparative theologians have noted parallels between Rama and Christ as divine figures who suffer and triumph

christianComparativeNotes.overview: Rama has been the subject of interfaith dialogue since the 19th century. While there is no patristic engagement (the Church Fathers did not know the Ramayana), modern comparative theology has explored meaningful parallels while respecting differences.
christianComparativeNotes.incarnation: Both Rama and Christ are divine beings who take human form‚ÄîRama as Vishnu's avatar, Christ as the eternal Word made flesh (John 1:14). Both descend to defeat evil and restore righteousness.
christianComparativeNotes.exileAndHumility: Rama's willing acceptance of exile to honor his father parallels Christ's kenosis‚Äîemptying himself of divine prerogatives (Philippians 2:6-8). Both choose suffering over power.
christianComparativeNotes.rescueOfTheBeloved: Rama rescues Sita (often interpreted as the soul held captive by demonic forces). Christian theologians have compared this to Christ rescuing the Church, his bride, from Satan's captivity.
christianComparativeNotes.victoryOverEvil: Rama's defeat of Ravana parallels Christ's defeat of Satan. Both represent cosmic victory of good over evil, restoration of divine order.
christianComparativeNotes.righteousKingship: Rama-rajya, the ideal kingdom, parallels the Kingdom of God. Both represent eschatological hope for perfect rule.
christianComparativeNotes.sufferingRighteousness: Both Rama and Christ suffer despite their righteousness‚Äîindeed, because of it. Their suffering has redemptive significance for others.
christianComparativeNotes.missionaryEncounter: 19th-century missionaries in India grappled with Rama's popularity. Some dismissed Hindu devotion; others (like Roberto de Nobili earlier) saw praeparatio evangelica in Hindu longing for divine incarnation and rescue from evil.
keyDistinctions: Rama is an avatar (descent); Christ is the eternal Son who takes on human nature permanently
Rama's mission is to defeat one demon king; Christ's mission is to defeat sin and death universally
Rama's suffering is imposed by circumstance; Christ's is voluntary atonement for sin
Rama establishes an earthly utopia; Christ's kingdom is 'not of this world' (John 18:36)
There is no concept of vicarious atonement in Rama's story; Christ dies for others' sins

sources: Valmiki Ramayana (c. 5th-4th century BCE): The original Sanskrit epic, 24,000 verses in seven kandas.
Tulsidas, Ramcharitmanas (16th century CE): Hindi retelling that made Rama devotion accessible to the masses.
Kamban, Ramavataram (12th century CE): Tamil version with distinct theological emphasis.
Adhyatma Ramayana (14th-15th century CE): Vedantic interpretation of the epic.
Various Southeast Asian versions: Thai Ramakien, Khmer Reamker, Indonesian Kakawin Ramayana.
modernScholarship: Robert Goldman (ed.), The Ramayana of Valmiki (1984-2017): Critical scholarly translation
Philip Lutgendorf, Hanuman's Tale (2007): Study of Hanuman devotion
